post: Meet BRIs 2025 Student Fellow, Abigail Huffman! She is a junior at Forest Hills Eastern High School in Grand Rapids, Michigan. She is actively involved in varsity soccer, Model UN, DECA, Youth in Government, and the district Student Advisory Council. Outside of school, Abigail channels her passion for politics into meaningful work with youth political organizations and proudly represents Michigan as a National Youth Advocate for the YMCA. When not studying or engaged in civic work, she enjoys traveling, camping, and listening to musicespecially Taylor Swift. BRIs Student Fellowship is a six-month educational program that helps high school students develop as leaders and develop skills in building civil society. Learn more about the Fellowship!  https://bit.ly/3f2q66h

Deadline Alert! Our MyImpact Challenge contest closes May 18 at 11:59 PM! Showcase your impact and win: 🏆 $10,000 Grand Prize 🥇 $7,500 First Prize 🥈 $5,000 Second Prize 🥉 $2,000 Third Prize Students! Apply now -  https://bit.ly/3YCS9wE

Help us identify the next National Civics Teacher of the Year! This Teacher Appreciation Week, nominate a civics teacher who inspires students to understand and engage with the world around them.  https://bit.ly/3qTvZIg

In the latest episode of our Honoring Service YouTube series, BRI's Gerald Gangaram discusses civic virtue and responsibility with former Air Force engineer Amanda Krantz. Krantz has served in a variety of positions in the Air Force, at Lockheed Martin Missiles and Space, and with NASA. Currently she is the Vice President of Finance and Business Development at Kalogon, an engineering and manufacturing company that designs seating for customers like wheelchair users, pilots, and drivers. Krantz has always desired to improve peoples lives with technology. Let her story inspire yours!  https://bit.ly/3Sg5MhL

Are you planning summer travel? Give back to BRI while you travel! Through our partnership with TravelingToGIVE.com, every purchase you make will help support BRI. Whether you are traveling somewhere warm or checking out a new city, your trip can help fund civic education programs and resources. Book today to make a difference,  https://lnkd.in/epqqzbzz

In our latest episode of Scholar Talks, BRI Senior Fellow Tony Williams is joined by historian John Bicknell to discuss the complex relationship between John C. Frémont and Abraham Lincoln and their differing approaches to slavery, emancipation, and presidential power. Drawing from his book Lincolns Pathfinder: John C. Frémont and the Violent Election of 1856, Bicknell discusses Frémonts controversial 1861 emancipation proclamation in Missouri, Lincolns revocation of the order, and how the presidents views evolved over timeultimately echoing Frémonts justification of military necessity in the Emancipation Proclamation of 1863. Watch it today!  https://bit.ly/4jMdADY

Meet BRIs 2025 Student Fellow, Yu-Cheng Liang! He is a junior at Camas High School in Camas, Washington. Most of his time is spent playing chess, where he is currently at the National Master rank. Besides chess, he loves to play the violin and study. High school studentsready to grow as a thinker, speaker, and leader? Join the Debate & Leadership Institute in historic Valley Forge! Engage in civil discourse, sharpen your leadership, and connect with peers from across the country. 🗓️ Apply by Friday, May 16 🎓 Open to rising 10th–12th graders 📍 Valley Forge, PA + Philadelphia day trip Built for students who want to lead with principle and purpose. https://bit.ly/3Z810qb

Happy Teacher Appreciation Week! 🎉 Today, we celebrate the incredible dedication and hard work of civics, history, and government teachers around the country who tackle complex topics and inspire students to understand and engage with the world around them. Teachers! We need your voice! Please take a moment to complete a brief survey to share your insights and experiences.  https://bit.ly/3RQEZIw

What defines legitimate executive power, and who holds the President accountable? Explore these questions in our new civic education resource ➡️ Government and Politics: Civics for the American Experiment. This free, customizable digital textbook, Government and Politics: Civics for the American Experiment, is ready for use in classrooms today or next school year! It covers all of the topics on the AP Government and Politics exam. This brand-new Core Resource contains primary sources, scholar-written essays, videos, tabletop games, and interactive elements!  https://bit.ly/3Z1NUe0
